thread.title: Denver approves incentives for Target on 16th Street Mall – The Denver Post
thread.title_full: Denver approves incentives for Target on 16th Street Mall – The Denver Post

author: Jon Murray
title: Denver approves incentives for Target on 16th Street Mall – The Denver Post
text:
Access to birth control widens as Colorado pharmacists prepare to prescribe oral contraceptives 
An urban Target store in downtown Denver came a step closer to reality Monday when the Denver City Council approved an incentives package valued at up to $4 million. 
The Minneapolis-based retailer is in talks with the landlord of the California Mall building at 1600 California St., facing the 16th Street Mall. The building, owned by Gart Properties , once was home to a food court, but it has sat mostly empty for more than a decade. 
City officials see an opportunity to bolster an underdeveloped block that’s across California from a light-rail stop. If Target signs a lease, current plans call for a 28,130-square-foot urban store — much smaller than a normal Target — that would focus on serving the growing ranks of downtown residents and workers, according to city documents. 
The council, voting 8-1, approved the incentives package for Sixteen Cal LLC, an entity registered to the Gart family. Related Articles June 5, 2012 Target looking at downtown Denver sites for urban store 
With the same vote, council members also accepted the filing of an appropriation ordinance that, if approved March 6, would pay for the deal. It would transfer $4 million from this year’s general fund budget contingency to the business incentive fund. 
Councilwoman Robin Kniech voted no, citing the rarity of using the city’s business incentive fund to support retail jobs that would pay wages below the area’s median, and typically for part-time work. She said a second factor was that the contract was with the landlord, not with Target — providing less assurance that the retailer would stick around in that location. 
“The combination of those two concerns — I just can’t get there,” Kniech said. 
But council President Albus Brooks, who represents much of downtown, and Councilman Paul López disagreed that retailers shouldn’t be eligible for incentives. Both said the city should use incentives more often for targeted retail purposes, such as attracting grocery stores to Denver’s food deserts. 
In the Target deal, the city’s arrangement with the landlord sets out a $2 million advance payment for tenant-required improvements upon store opening and up to $2 million more for an operational offset. The latter would come in the form of 50 percent rebates of sales and use taxes generated by the store for up to 20 years. 
After that limit is hit, the landlord’s 50 percent split would go toward repaying the city for the $2 million advance payment. Tags:
